description: Fourteenth Amendment due process in surveillance context
facts: State law enforcement conducted surveillance program
Program targeted individuals without individualized suspicion
No procedural safeguards or notice provided
Surveillance data used in criminal proceedings
Defendants had no opportunity to challenge surveillance before use

question: Does surveillance without procedural safeguards violate Fourteenth Amendment due process?
rationale: The Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause requires that state action depriving persons of liberty or property interests provide adequate procedural protections. Surveillance programs affecting fundamental privacy interests must include procedural safeguards such as individualized suspicion, notice, and opportunity to challenge the surveillance.
